articles.headline: What Organizations Don’t Want to Know Can Hurt
articles.snippet: The leaders of corporations and other institutions, it turns out, are not always hungry for more information after mistakes are made.
articles.abstract: The leaders of corporations and other institutions, it turns out, are not always hungry for more information after mistakes are made.
articles.lead_paragraph: Call in Miss Marple, perhaps, or Sherlock Holmes.

articles.headline: Rohatyn Will Take Lehman Post
articles.snippet: Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker who helped New York City avert bankruptcy in the 1970’s, is joining Lehman Brothers as a senior adviser to its chairman.
articles.abstract: Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker who helped New York City avert bankruptcy in the 1970’s, is joining Lehman Brothers as a senior adviser to its chairman.
articles.lead_paragraph: Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker who helped New York City avert bankruptcy in the 1970’s and became the ambassador to France in the late 1990’s, is joining Lehman Brothers as a senior adviser to its chairman.

articles.headline: Britain Charges 11 in Plane Case; Bomb Gear Cited
articles.snippet: The decision to press formal charges followed days of widening public skepticism about the extent of the suspected plot.
articles.abstract: The decision to press formal charges followed days of widening public skepticism about the extent of the suspected plot.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON, Aug. 21 — The British authorities charged 11 people on Monday in connection with a suspected plot to blow up United States-bound airliners, and said investigators had discovered “martyrdom videos” and bomb-making materials in a far-reaching search of homes, cars, woodland and other locations.

articles.headline: AOL Moves to Increase Privacy on Search Queries
articles.snippet: AOL’s chief technology officer departed after the company released hundreds of thousands of its customers’ search queries.
articles.abstract: AOL’s chief technology officer departed after the company released hundreds of thousands of its customers’ search queries.
articles.lead_paragraph: AOL announced the resignation of its chief technology officer yesterday, two weeks after the company came under intense criticism from privacy advocates for releasing hundreds of thousands of its customers’ Web search queries.

articles.headline: Slow Start for Revival of Nuclear Reactors
articles.snippet: Utility executives are sharply divided over whether nuclear power offers an attractive choice as they seek to satisfy a growing demand for electricity.
articles.abstract: Utility executives are sharply divided over whether nuclear power offers an attractive choice as they seek to satisfy a growing demand for electricity.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Nobody in the United States has started building a nuclear power plant in more than three decades. Mayo A. Shattuck III could be the first.

articles.headline: Britain Charges 11 in Plane Case; Bomb Gear Cited
articles.snippet: The British authorities charged 11 people on Monday in connection with a suspected plot to blow up United States-bound airliners, and said investigators had discovered ''martyrdom videos'' and bomb-making materials in a far-reaching search of home...
articles.abstract: The British authorities charged 11 people on Monday in connection with a suspected plot to blow up United States-bound airliners, and said investigators had discovered ''martyrdom videos'' and bomb-making materials in a far-reaching search of homes, cars, woodland and other locations.      At least 8 of the 11 were thought to form a hard core of bombers who planned to assemble liquid-based explosives on board airplanes and detonate them, they said.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON, Aug. 21 - The British authorities charged 11 people on Monday in connection with a suspected plot to blow up United States-bound airliners, and said investigators had discovered "martyrdom videos" and bomb-making materials in a far-reaching search of homes, cars, woodland and other locations.

articles.headline: Officials Seek Broader Access to Airline Data
articles.snippet: United States and European authorities, looking for more tools to detect terrorist plots, want to expand the screening of international airline passengers by digging deep into a vast repository of airline itineraries, personal information and paym...
articles.abstract: United States and European authorities, looking for more tools to detect terrorist plots, want to expand the screening of international airline passengers by digging deep into a vast repository of airline itineraries, personal information and payment data.     A proposal by Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff would allow the United States government not only to look for known terrorists on watch lists, but also to search broadly through the passenger itinerary data to identify people who may be linked to terrorists, he said in a recent interview.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 - United States and European authorities, looking for more tools to detect terrorist plots, want to expand the screening of international airline passengers by digging deep into a vast repository of airline itineraries, personal information and payment data.

articles.headline: Slow Start for Revival of Nuclear Reactors
articles.snippet: Nobody in the United States has started building a nuclear power plant in more than three decades. Mayo A. Shattuck III could be the first.      As the chief executive of Constellation Energy, a utility holding company in Baltimore that already op...
articles.abstract: Nobody in the United States has started building a nuclear power plant in more than three decades. Mayo A. Shattuck III could be the first.      As the chief executive of Constellation Energy, a utility holding company in Baltimore that already operates five nuclear reactors, Mr. Shattuck is convinced that nuclear power is on the verge of a renaissance, ready to provide reliable electricity at a competitive price. He has already taken the first steps toward achieving that, moving recently to order critical parts for a new reactor.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE - Nobody in the United States has started building a nuclear power plant in more than three decades. Mayo A. Shattuck III could be the first.

articles.headline: In Election Push, Bush Faults Talk of Iraq Pullout
articles.snippet: President Bush seized on Monday on Democratic calls for withdrawal from Iraq to make an election-year case that his political rivals did not properly understand the threats to the nation and would create a more dangerous world.      It was the mos...
articles.abstract: President Bush seized on Monday on Democratic calls for withdrawal from Iraq to make an election-year case that his political rivals did not properly understand the threats to the nation and would create a more dangerous world.      It was the most direct attack on Democrats that Mr. Bush has made from a White House lectern this election year, and it effectively signaled the beginning of a more outright political season for him and his aides as they work to help Republicans maintain control of Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 - President Bush seized on Monday on Democratic calls for withdrawal from Iraq to make an election-year case that his political rivals did not properly understand the threats to the nation and would create a more dangerous world.

articles.headline: Debating Security in Germany
articles.snippet: The disclosure that a bomb plot involved a 21-year-old Lebanese is reshaping debate over what latitude to give security forces. Page A8.
articles.abstract: The disclosure that a bomb plot involved a 21-year-old Lebanese is reshaping debate over what latitude to give security forces. Page A8.
articles.lead_paragraph: The disclosure that a bomb plot involved a 21-year-old Lebanese is reshaping debate over what latitude to give security forces. Page A8.

articles.headline: What Organizations Don’t Want to Know Can Hurt
articles.snippet: Call in Miss Marple, perhaps, or Sherlock Holmes.     Maybe they could solve the mystery of how some of the College Board's SAT exams became wet last October, resulting in mistaken scores on more than 5,000 tests.
articles.abstract: Call in Miss Marple, perhaps, or Sherlock Holmes.     Maybe they could solve the mystery of how some of the College Board's SAT exams became wet last October, resulting in mistaken scores on more than 5,000 tests.
articles.lead_paragraph: Call in Miss Marple, perhaps, or Sherlock Holmes.

articles.headline: Rohatyn Will Take Lehman Post
articles.snippet: Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker who helped New York City avert bankruptcy in the 1970's and became the ambassador to France in the late 1990's, is joining Lehman Brothers as a senior adviser to its chairman.      The appointment will put M...
articles.abstract: Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker who helped New York City avert bankruptcy in the 1970's and became the ambassador to France in the late 1990's, is joining Lehman Brothers as a senior adviser to its chairman.      The appointment will put Mr. Rohatyn, 78, perhaps Wall Street's most elder statesman, back in the thick of the worldwide boom of mergers and acquisitions. And it will give Lehman Brothers, which has made significant gains as one of the nation's top deal makers, a powerful brand name with a vast list of high-powered relationships as it seeks to expand its business, especially in Europe and Asia.
articles.lead_paragraph: Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker who helped New York City avert bankruptcy in the 1970's and became the ambassador to France in the late 1990's, is joining Lehman Brothers as a senior adviser to its chairman.

articles.headline: AOL Moves to Increase Privacy on Search Queries
articles.snippet: AOL announced the resignation of its chief technology officer yesterday, two weeks after the company came under intense criticism from privacy advocates for releasing hundreds of thousands of its customers' Web search queries.     An AOL researche...
articles.abstract: AOL announced the resignation of its chief technology officer yesterday, two weeks after the company came under intense criticism from privacy advocates for releasing hundreds of thousands of its customers' Web search queries.     An AOL researcher who put the queries online and a manager overseeing the project were dismissed, according to an AOL employee who did not want to be identified because the company does not comment publicly on personnel matters.
articles.lead_paragraph: AOL announced the resignation of its chief technology officer yesterday, two weeks after the company came under intense criticism from privacy advocates for releasing hundreds of thousands of its customers' Web search queries.
